title: Meet the latest Dope Sandwich crew member: Lady Valore
text:
Photos Back | Next Photo by Adriana Iris Boatwright Lady Valore Back | Next Photo by Adriana Iris Boatwright Lady Valore
By ADRIANA IRIS BOATWRIGHT
D ope Sandwich now has a female rapper in the family.
During our photo shoot, Lady Valore brought me to tears with her rhymes.
While they are filled with intensity, the fact that I recognize women warriors when I see them helped me feel even deeper the rhymes she was spitting.
Elaina Valore was born in New Jersey but raised in Marietta, the daughter of an accountant who found rap in Shakespeare. Valore discovered her strength and voice as a participant in children’s theater; it was her vehicle on the wooden boards of the stage.
Inspired by the local scene more than anything mainstream, her preference leans on alternative music and is more deep than any of the rap you hear on the radio.
What moves her? She replies with a smile: “Raw energy and what woos me? Exactly that.
“I want my brain to be tickled first.”
Then she begins to spit a rhyme at me ...
Valore is just 21 years old, so I asked in her opinion, what defines millennials?
“Definitely social media. Seems to define most in my age bracket. I, too, am a victim of it,” she admits. “I find myself checking up on Instagram constantly. There is such information overload.”
Why is there such need?
“It’s almost like a high,” she says. “Instant gratification. It’s right there in the palm of your hands.”
What is her war song?
With eyes filled with pure melancholia, she responds: “I am tired of the [filtered word]-shaming. I am tired of women being seen as objects. I am tired of others hating. Lately I found most of my strength in the negative; it fuels me. I turn around and return a sick rhyme filled with positivity and love.”
And so she begins to spit another rhyme ...
ODE TO THE 912
Savannah is as slow as molasses
We’re all trapped in this
Slow sultry swell
The elderly sit on the porch and dwell
On the humidity
We’re rooted to this town like the oak tree
I don’t think I’ll ever break free
From the hypnotizing dripping of the Spanish moss
Your forehead has a gloss of sweat
As you tell me your regrets
How you took a bite of the sweetest of all the Georgia peaches
And she left you in pieces
Bikes crammed in hallways
The churches always
Ringing every sunday
There’s enough steeples here to repent ever sinner ten-fold
I’m told
However my sanctuary is the swamp
How it never fails to haunt my bones
There’s this dark undertone
Resonating through the streets
If you listen carefully you can hear history’s heartbeat
Diversity thriving in squares
Share a pedicab with me
And you’ll see from the scenery why so many people want to be stuck
In such a city
Trolleys and sunshine
Cobblestone and fine wine
Trendy fashion and horse-drawn carriages
Saxophones and evangelical images
Forsyth a place for a spectrum of people
Midnight in the garden of good and evil
As pretty as seems there are dark alleys
Shootings almost daily
Numb to the police sirens
Ambulances screaming, shining like diamonds
Black feral kittens adorning every doorstep
Searching for someone to let them in
Trying to sweep the streets of sin in the dark
Can’t find a place to park
Would Dr. King be proud of what MLK Boulevard has become?
Children holding up people with guns
Ornate houses decayed and empty
Glocks go well with blunts and 40s
Mothers begging at the DFCS for food stamps
Can’t provide for a family cramping in hunger
Dirty kids don’t trust one another
Stabbing each other
Sipping whiskey as they lose sanity
Not allowing people to play music unless they have a license
Losing the essence of being free
By ticketing lovely strings
18 but not allowed in bars
Fake IDs fill up jars
Graduated from college with a degree
Debt piled up to the ceiling
Getting by waitressing
Artists and gangsters
Tourists and travelers
Hippies and pastors
Yuppies and farmers
All together we strive to survive and thrive
In this microcosm divine
